blocks.text: The integral $\int \frac{dx}{(a+b)}$ reduces to $\frac{1}{n} \log \left| nu \, \log (a+b) \right|$, where $u = a + b$.

blocks.description: This equation shows the integral evaluation, relating it back to the logarithmic function.

blocks.text: It will be observed that the denominator is a third quantity; and in many such cases it is advisable to make a substitution that rationalizes the denominator. Thus in this case let $u = x^{1/2}$.

blocks.description: This equation shows the derivative of $x$ with respect to $u$ in the context of a substitution.
This equation shows the integral with the substitution applied.
